Award.AwardTitle: Mechanism of alpha catenin tension sensing

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1132116
Leckband

Intellectual merit. This program extends recent innovative findings by this team demonstrating that cadherin complexes--critical proteins at cell-to-cell junctions in all soft tissues--sense the mechanical properties of the cell environment and proportionally regulates cell functions. A major objective is to use sensitive force probes to test proposed mechanisms of mechano-sensing at cadherin junctions. A new innovation will be the development of a fluorescence-based intracellular biosensor to directly test whether mechanical force induces conformational changes in a putative force sensor at intercellular adhesions. This sensor will enable direct visualization of dynamic, force-actuated changes at cadherin-based adhesions in live cells. This will transform the ability to investigate mechanotransduction at intercellular junctions, and enable the real-time visualization of spatial maps of mechanotransduction, in a living cell. This multidisciplinary research involves sensitive mechanical measurements, probe development, and dynamic, subcellular imaging of live cells. This program is innovative because cadherin-based, intercellular mechanosensing and its impact on broader cell mechanics is an almost entirely unexplored research area.
This research will have broad impact because cadherins are critical for tissue genesis, organized tissue remodeling, and regulating tissue barriers. Cadherins' capacity to sense force would dramatically impact how they regulate cell functions, and expand the impact of mechanical force on cell-cell communication. Because cadherins are important for human health and tissue biology, this work will impact fields ranging from developmental biology to bioengineering and the clinic.
The educational impact lies in the outreach to women and minorities at pre-college and undergraduate levels through the "Girls Adventures in Mathematics and Engineering" (GAMES) program and with the Summer Research Opportunity Program for minorities (SROP) at the University of Illinois. This grant will enable the implementation of technologies described in this proposal in GAMES workshops and in SROP research projects, and the continued mentoring women and underrepresented minorities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The broad goal of this research was to develop a protein biosensor that would report dynamic force transduction at adhesive contacts between living cells. Specifically, we engineered a sensor that would report conformational changes in a protein nanomachine, in response to changes in tension at cell-to-cell contacts. This grant specifically focused on a key protein, alpha catenin that is a critical component of cadherin-mediated adhesive contacts between cells. Cadherins are the essential Velcro that holds cells together in all tissues, and alpha catenin is a postulated force transducer at these specialized adhesive contacts. Alpha catenin was proposed to convert changes in forces on cadherin adhesions into intracellular biochemical signals that regulate cell and tissue functions. The proposed mechanism by which this alpha catenin nanomachine converted force into biochemical changes involves a force-dependent change in the protein structure that exposes an important binding site for other proteins inside the cell. However, the occurrence of this force activated conformational switch inside living cells had not been directly demonstrated. Moreover, strategies for investigating this mechanism had typically involved fixing, staining, and imaging (dead) cells, and did not allow the direct visualization of dynamic force transduction events in living cells and in real time.  

This program addressed this challenge, by engineering an alpha catenin biosensor that would report force-dependent changes in alpha catenin in real time in living cells. In this engineered sensor, two fluorescent proteins were placed in the alpha catenin sequence on either side of the proposed force-sensing region of the alpha catenin structure. In this engineered protein, the two fluorescent proteins would be near each other in the relaxed (low tension) alpha catenin conformation, but a force-dependent change in the alpha catenin structure would separate the fluophores, resulting in a change in the optical signals generated by the sensor. We successfully engineered the sensor, and demonstrated force transduction in live cells under several different conditions.

The intellectual merit of this research was the successful engineering of a functional alpha catenin biosensor that responds to differences in tension at cadherin adhesions in living cells. With this sensor, we directly validated a postulated molecular mechanism of force transduction at cell-cell contacts in tissues.  We also identified spatial and temporal correlations between the force transduction event (alpha catenin conformation switching) and subsequent, linked biochemical changes in the cell in response to mechanical stimulation. This sensor further enabled us to directly visualize differences in force transduction at junctions between cells in different mechanical environments. In a collaboration with cell biologists at Northwestern and the University of Toronto, we also identified effects of the post-translational modification of alpha catenin on cell adhesion and migration. Cadherin based adhesion and force transduction are crucial for a host of critical cellular functions such as the regulation of cell shape, cell proliferation, and differentiation. This engineered sensor now provides a powerful tool for visualizing force transduction at these important adhesive junctions in living cells and tissues.

The broader impacts of this research include impact on other disciplines, opportunities for training graduate students in engineering, and outreach to elementary and middle school girls.  Researchers in cell and developmental biology are already using our engineered sensor to investigate force transduction during different stages of development in flies and other model organisms. Biophysicists and cell biologists are also using our sensor to study force transduction in model systems and in tissues. The plasmids encoding different forms of the sensor were deposited with Addgene, in order to enable its broader dissemination to the wider scientific community.

Graduate students and the PI on this grant also participated in different outreach activities that exposed elementary and middle school girls to novel challenges and professional opportunities in science and engineering.  We participated in the Bonding with Chemistry summer program organized by Chemistry that exposes elementary school girls to different applications of chemistry in daily life. Through the Girls Adventures in Mathematics, Engineering and Sciences (GAMES) summer camp, we exposed girls to exciting research and professional opportunities in bioengineering.
